Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectrometer to Support Research Projects from C-H Bond Oxidation to Engineered Molecular Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Professor Duy Hua from Kansas State University and colleagues Daniel Higgins, Stefan Bossmann, Jun Li and Emily McLaurin have acquired a hybrid 400 MHz NMR spectrometer with solution and solid-state capabilities. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as allow study of biologically relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The instrument positively impacts researchers across Kansas, particularly those primarily undergraduate institutions in the region. The team has cyber-infrastructure available to users to receive, manipulate and analyze the spectra remotely.

The award of this hybrid NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts areas such as catalytic asymmetric C-H bond oxidation of alkanes and the synthesis of oligopeptides and fluorescent dyes. The spectrometer is used tocharacterize single molecule fluorescence of aldol condensation on heterogeneous catalysts and rapidly profilling protease using a multiplex method. In addition, it aids microwave-assisted ionic liquid etching of colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals and the synthesis of dye derivatives for studies of heterogeneous nanostructures. The instrument also serves researchers studyingf A- and B-class dye-decolorizing peroxidases lignin degradation mechanism and applications and supramolecular chemistry of chalcogen/halogen or hydrogen bonding. Finally, the instrumentation is also used to identify bio-inspired metal-organic-framework (MOFs) for applications in nanotheranostics, and for mechanistic investigations of olefin methathesis catalysts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

Project title: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectrometer to Support Research Projects from C-H Bond Oxidation to Engineered Molecular Materials

PI: Duy H. Hua

Awardee: Kansas State University

Award Number: 1826982

Award Ends:  07/31/2021

Program Officer Name:  Carlos Murillo

Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) instrumentation is essential for the characterization of molecular structures in organic and inorganic compounds, nanomaterials, and polymers.  The awarded instrument, a solution/solid-state NMR spectrometer, serves as a workhorse instrument and supports various NSF-awarded research programs in our Department and in others across our campus to characterize their soluble and insoluble materials, expanding existing capability and enabling cutting-edge investigations.  The instrument also uses in teaching our undergraduate and graduate courses such as Organic Chemistry 1 and 2, Advanced Organic and Inorganic Techniques Laboratories, and Organic Spectroscopy along with NSF-funded Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program during the summer months. Ten researcher groups involving approximate five postdoctoral fellows, thirty-one graduate students and twenty-five undergraduate students annually, use the NMR instrument routinely for their research projects. Research projects include: (1) catalytic carbon-hydrogen bond oxidation of small molecules, bioactive molecules and natural products, (2) development of anti-Alzheimer molecules, (3) design of specific substrate peptides for profiling of overexpressed proteases in the detection of triple-negative breast cancers, (4) syntheses of organic molecules and nanomaterials for cancer diagnostics and treatment, (5) fluorescent dyes and designer peptides for single cell analysis in microfluidic devices, (6) magnetic-imaging guided hyperthermia using heterogeneous nanostructures, (7) characterization of hybrid electrode materials on nanostructured carbon templates for batteries, (8) vertically aligned carbon nanofibers with cup-stacking graphitic structure as N-doped metal free catalysts, (9) platinum-catalyst supports for oxygen reduction in low-temperature fuel cells, (10) mechanism and application of dye-decolorizing peroxidases, (11) selectivity in host-guest chemistry, (12) crystal engineering with exotic intermolecular interactions, (13) catalysis and nanotheranostics of metal-organic framework, and (14) iron-alkylidene catalysts in olefin metathesis.  Eleven published and submitted articles along with numerous presentations were resulted from these research projects.  Funding from NSF MRI program was acknowledged in these publications and presentations.  Intellectual merit includes: (1) the discovery of novel catalysts for the transformation of bioactive natural products and drugs into possible new drugs, (2) studies of the capture and release of DNA from coated electrode surfaces, (3) optimization of the effect of immune-stimulating hyperthermia on solid tumors and migration of tumor cells, (4)  application of hybrid structures based on vertical carbon nanofiber arrays coated with active manganese dioxide shells for use in high-performance supercapacitors and lithium ion batteries, and others.  Broader impact: The awarded NMR instrument not only has great impact on our research but also affects our education and training activities for undergraduate and graduate students. Students routinely use the instrument to characterize their molecules and to study reaction mechanisms including the uses of modern two-dimensional NMR spectroscopy.  Users from other departments such as Grain Science and Industry and Chemical Engineering also use the instrument for their research projects.  Our NMR Instrument Director, Simon Sham, offers an NMR course annually introducing NMR operational procedures along with one- and two-dimensional NMR spectroscopy and interpretation of the spectra. REU students from primarily undergraduate universities including underprivileged students are actively recruited to our summer program to conduct research, in which NMR instrument contributes greatly in their education.  Funding from NSF MRI program acknowledged in their presentations.  Generally, REU students have no access to the high-field NMR instrumentation in their alma maters, hence students benefit greatly from the knowledge acquired through the application of NMR spectroscopy in sciences.
